texts.shortText: Common, attractive and well-known species popular with anglers. Head elongate and projecting, with long, sloping forehead and protrusible terminal mouth. Silvery in colour with numerous black spots on body (but not on head) and a black patch on hind edge of operculum. Juveniles without spots but retain the dark patch on operculum.
Up to 90 cm length and 10 kg in mass.

Global: Widespread in tropical and warm-temperate Indian Ocean from South Africa to India, including Madagascar and Seychelles.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.

Found over sandy bottoms in shallow coastal waters and in estuaries. Sensitive to cold waters and extend into False Bay mainly only in summer. Feed by adopting an upright posture and plunging the jaws into the sediments, taking in mouthfuls of sand, sifting out burrowing invertebrates and expelling the waste sediment from the gill openings. Juveniles found mostly in estuaries.
Feeds on burrowing crustaceans such as sand and mud-prawns and on bivalves.

Matures at length of 36 cm in females and 30 cm in males (both at 3 years of age). Usually spawns at sea from August to December in the eastern part of the range, but also recorded spawning in estuaries. Juveniles enter estuaries in spring and summer and remain there for about a year before returning to the sea at 17–20 cm length.

Easily identified by the elongate head and distinctive spots on the body. The Cock grunter P. multimaculatus is also spotted, but the dots also extend onto the head and the species is found only from Algoa Bay eastwards.
